metadata.debate_title: HEATED Rittenhouse Debate w/ Sam Seder

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: He now is going out and monetizing it. It's gross. And you and I can disagree on that, but nothing I'm saying is factually incorrect whatsoever.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: It's not just, hold on, this is such a- You pretended, you came up with a hypothetical accusing me if it was a different race that I would be so ecstatic about it, I would be guzzling their buckets of cum. If I said that George Floyd died after being arrested for trying to buy something with counterfeit money with fentanyl in a system, do you think that that's okay to say, even though factually everything I just said was correct? Or would you say, well, hold on, the framing here is a little bit dishonest.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: So I emailed you relating to Rittenhouse stuff. Before we dive like too deep into things, I guess something that I've been kind of noticing that's like broadly occurring across the United States is I've noticed that there is like a, there's a really big fixation on changing processes and focusing on processes as being broken to kind of effect change legislatively or whatever. And it seems like people have kind of given up on ever having like a cohesive United States where we can kind of agree on some things again. So like, for instance, people will talk about like getting rid of the filibuster, completely changing how we gerrymander, rebalancing the Senate, making Puerto Rico a state, getting rid of the electoral college. Like these are like the, we're all the focuses. And we've kind of just like given up on like, there's no way that we're ever gonna agree on on certain things anymore. So I guess when I have conversations with people, especially people that I disagree with, conservatives, I usually try to start from a point of like common understanding, like, okay, what are some things that we do agree on that are real? And then from there, we kind of like move to other conversations, I guess. Does that make sense?

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: It does. I don't necessarily agree with your characterization, the premise to do that. But I mean, it's not, I mean, the filibuster has been changed before, I think probably three or four times, at least more. It was changed a year ago to raise the debt ceiling. I mean, so I don't think that's as dramatic of a process change. And people have been talking about getting rid of the electoral college for at least 25 years. I mean, I remember talking about it in college, that would have been 30, 35 years ago.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Yeah, I'm not, I don't mean to say any of those ideas are necessarily bad. It just, it feels like people feel like that's where the, like 100% of the fight is, is on changing those institutions rather than, and then like the whole media landscape has kind of been given up. We've all kind of like dug into our holes and those guys aren't gonna be convinced. We just have to figure out how to change the process enough to get whatever we want legislatively done.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: I think the reason why we're hearing a lot more about that is because we're, I mean, I think it's inarguable that we are as close to minoritarian rule as we've ever had in this country. If you look at how many people are represented by the Republicans in the Senate versus the Democrats, you're gonna see tens of millions of unbalance there. That in a 50-50 Senate, you have literally tens, 40 million, I think more Americans represented by the 50 Democrats than the 50 Republicans. You've seen two out of the last three presidential elections that elected a Republican with a, with not, never mind, without, not only, not without a majority, without a plurality of the votes. You're seeing, you know, gerrymandering that leads to a disbalance in votes in places like Wisconsin and Pennsylvania. I mean, those actually have been fixed because of the state Supreme Courts, but in the past where more than 50% of people vote for a Democratic candidate and the Republicans have 65% of the representation there. And when you look at the Supreme Court, I mean, people have been wanting to reform that for a long time as well, but it's, I think, particularly problematic where you have those two presidents who didn't win a majority of the votes have placed the six Republican or Supreme Court nominees on there, so.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Yeah, and I would even point to Garland as like even a more egregious example of like a destruction of a process to get another conservative justice on the Supreme Court.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: I absolutely agree.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Like I said, I'm not saying that any of these institutions are infallible or beyond change or intractable. We can't do anything about them. I think that all of it should be open for conversation. But would you agree that we are historically, as a people, independent of our institutions, like divided more than we probably ever have been due to the acceleration of like technology moving us into different groups?

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: I wouldn't say ever we did have a civil war where 500,000 people died.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: That is true.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: That, I would say, was a little bit more of a division. But I think certainly in the post-world era, without a doubt, we are as divided as possible. I mean, in 1950, the complaint was that there was virtually no daylight between the two parties. And that was a complaint. I mean, so, yeah, we are, you know, but that is the nature of politics, I think.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Sure. Yeah, I kind of agree with the nature of politics, but I feel like the technological aspect and then the kind of the, as much of a capitalist as I am, I think for-profit media combined with like the entertaining parts of it, combined with all the technology, has like accelerated these two worlds apart, such that like this kind of like urban-rural divide in the United States, really across the entire western world, is pretty unreal in terms of differences in beliefs between groups of people. Not just differences in beliefs in terms of what's right or wrong, but differences in beliefs in terms of like the reality of what's actually happening in situations. I think that's like my biggest worry, because it feels like we live in totally different realities now, completely.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: I think there is no doubt that technology has exacerbated this. But, you know, this dynamic, the rural, you know, urban dynamic, I can tell you that 20 some odd years ago, I went down to Cuba, my then wife was doing a documentary, had a NOFAC license, so it was perfectly legal. But, at that time, what Castro would do is he would bring police in from the rural areas to police in Havana, because of that rural-urban divide. And, I mean, so, and I can assure you the technology, the communications technology there was not, you know, it was, well, first of all, it was 20 years ago, so we didn't have, but there was no internet per se there in the way that we understand it. And so, I mean, I think, but there's no doubt, technology has exacerbated it, you know, it heightened the gerrymandering, I think, too, to make it so efficient. But I would agree with all that. But, yes, we are highly polarized.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Okay, so, with the broader, the macro picture out of the way, looking at the microscopic stuff, so, there are a lot of things that get brought up by mainstream and alternative media, where I feel like the messaging, I think, is, the messaging can be okay, but it's poisoned because all of the facts beneath it are wrong. And when those facts are wrong, I think you lose the ability to communicate any of your broader messaging to, like, a wider audience. I think a really good example of this is, I think Joe Rogan was highly irresponsible for having so much, like, Bunk Medicine introduced to huge audiences on his show, like Ivermectin. But when CNN starts saying things like, Ivermectin is just a drug for horses, it's only horse paste. Well, I mean, like, one Google search away, we can see that's not true. And then all of a sudden, Joe Rogan is spreading bad information about medicine. That message, which is true, becomes undermined, I think, because people are getting some of the facts wrong. And then, now coming more specifically, I feel like with the Rittenhouse stuff, I feel like Rittenhouse is pretty cut and dry a lot of different ways, but I still hear people get a lot of the, kind of, like, facts or analysis, in my opinion, like, really wrong. So, I think the thing I want to talk to you about is there's, like, three main points that I, we'll see if I can move you on any of them. Number one is I think that the riots in Kenosha were literally propagated by fake news. They should have never happened. I think that Rittenhouse had just as much reason to be in Kenosha as any other person that was there. I think that all of the Rittenhouse killings were the two, and then the one shooting the guy's bicep were all in self-defense and had nothing to do with defending property. These are three points that I see repeated the opposite way by left-leaning mainstream and alternative media over and over and over again. I think that all three are, like, clearly wrong.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: Okay, I mean, I, the first one in terms of you don't agree with the Kenosha protest seems to me to be, I mean, largely irrelevant in terms of Rittenhouse in my estimation. I mean, I, you know, I don't want to litigate whether people should have been upset and, you know, should be upset about policing in this country relative to black people in particular. I mean, that to me is, and you can argue that the Kenosha, you know, protests were set off by, you know, Blake's killing. Well, Blake's shooting, right? Shooting, sorry. And I guess he's paralyzed. And you could argue that it was just that without any of the context of the protests that had been going on across the country and the building, you know, literally decades. I mean, I would tell this story for years on my show. When I was in straight entertainment, I did a sitcom called The Show. And it was a white head writer on an all-black variety show. And one of the guys I worked with was a guy named Chris Spencer. And Chris, we went back to his house at a break during a shooting or rehearsal or whatever it was. And we pull into his garage in West Hollywood. And we get followed as we come in by his buddy in a Range Rover. And at that time, that was like the, if you were successful in L.A., you had a Range Rover. And this was, again, this was in the mid-90s. And the guy comes in, he's like, thank God you were there. I got, I was being followed by the cops again for the fourth time this week because they pulled me over three times to check and see if this was my car. And he said he had called the police department and spoke to a sergeant. It was like, is there a sticker I can get that says this is my car? And the cop said, are you black? And he said, yes. And he said, there's really nothing I can do for you. And so, I mean, this has been going on, well, far before that. But certainly, you know, at least in terms of our lifetime, has been going on and on. So I think you can say people should not have been upset by the shooting of Blake. And that was the only reason why they protested and they protested on false grounds. But I mean, I don't even think that's worth litigating. People can make their own determination as to whether those protests were justified. As far as the second one that you said was-

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Can we move through one at a time, I think?

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: Sure.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Yeah. So on the first one, so when I'm thinking of like how I want to deal with a particular thing, I usually try to think of like, well, what happens on the other side? I want to be able to, have you ever heard of the term stochastic terrorism? It's like this idea that like, if you give enough of a certain type of rhetoric, even if you don't directly call people to violence, there's probably going to be some violence that happens. So I would say like Tucker Carlson, when he talks about the great replacement over and over and over and over again, and then when some kid picks up a gun and he starts killing black people or like immigrants or whatever, it's pretty obvious that like, even if I can't draw a straight line from A to B, I can see how somebody could get from A to B. So I want to be able to condemn people on the right when they give irresponsible rhetoric that leads to things like shootings or things like the January 6th attempted coup insurrection. I want to be able to say, when you engage in this type of rhetoric or language, it's dangerous and it will cause people to do this. So I think for Kenosha, I wouldn't say that like an amalgamation of things led to those riots. I would say pretty clearly, it was absolutely the coverage of the Jacob Blake shooting. Jacob Blake was shot on August 23rd. There were riots that day and on the 24th and on the 25th was the Rittenhouse shooting. That timeline of like three days is not an accident. It was very clearly the video went out of Jacob Blake being shot. Every left-leaning media person in the world jumped on it, started blasting it all over Twitter, all over social media, all over mainstream media as like a poor innocent black guy that got shot in the back by cops six times. A lot of people still think he was killed even. I think that the misreporting and the mishandling of that was absolutely the biggest drive of those Kenosha riots that happened in the following days.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: I mean, you may have a point. I don't know, to be honest with you. I mean, I wouldn't know how to parse that out. And you can say that the coverage was poor and that in my mind has really, is in no way a mitigating factor in my mind for the actions that Rittenhouse took. So it's sort of irrelevant relative to my perception of Rittenhouse. I mean, there's, I take it as a granted that at any given time, news is sensationalistic. And the way that our media is organized now, it's sensationalistic, you know, depending on who they perceive their audience to be and et cetera, et cetera. I mean, there were protests, peaceful protests in that first day. At night, things turned ugly and, you know, maybe it is the media's fault or certain media outlets and not others. I mean, but I think like the impetus to protest, it's pretty hard to say that when you're talking about, you know, a, you know, a proceeding, whatever, 12, 18 months you want to say, where you've had some of the biggest protests about police shootings that the country has seen to say that that's completely divorced from that context. I mean, I think there's a very hard argument to make, but like I say, relative to Rittenhouse, none of that is relevant to me.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Okay, sure. Yeah, that's fine. And I would agree that other things are playing into it as well. Like I'm not going to argue against police, like even the facts of the matter relating to police bias. There was a huge, like over a hundred million traffic stops. The Veil of Darkness study that I think was published in Nature, Human Behavior, or whatever. I mean, so what you were talking about with your friend being pulled over in the Range Rover, like, yeah. I mean, these are pretty inarguable. So I wouldn't disagree with that. But the Kenosha stuff being spurred on by what I would consider to be essentially fake news was, I thought, a little bit troubling. But so for point two, I hear this a lot. It's repeated a lot. I've heard it on your show quite a few times. This idea that like Rittenhouse drove over state lines or he drove to a neighboring city. Like his dad lived in that city. He worked there as a lifeguard. It was like a 20 minute drive. I don't think that that, I think he had just as much right to be in that community as literally any other protester there.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: I don't think that's enough. I think the point, you know, when people say that in my estimation is that it's one thing to, I own a bodega or my dad owns a bodega, let's say. And I go down there and I sit in the bodega and maybe with a weapon, maybe not, and to protect that. And I think, look, we can't know what is in Kyle Rittenhouse's, you know, mind or heart in that moment. Maybe he felt such a close connection to that community that he, you know, that's what spurred him on to grab a gun and go down there and patrol or not. I mean, I don't know. You don't know. We can't know that. It is material insofar as, you know, crossing state lines makes it seem like it's further away. I don't know if I ever said crossing state lines. I mean, my understanding of why we're here is you saw a video of mine on Twitter and or through Twitter and you reached out to me that's conceivable. But, you know, I had very little coverage of the Rittenhouse case itself. In fact, none of the actual case. I think I did a video following the verdict, but it has been not so much, I guess a policy you could say, but just like I don't watch legal cases. I just find that not to be helpful. I didn't watch the O.J. Simpson trial. I wasn't in this business. I didn't watch the Johnny Depp and his girlfriend trial. I just don't watch trials. And I didn't watch the Zimmerman trial. I don't follow them. I don't cover them in general because I think, you know, that's where you have to try. It's a spectacle, I think.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Yeah, I remember you mentioning this. It seems a little bit dramatic. And I would agree that people definitely, I mean, we've seen that with the Amber Heard Johnny Depp stuff, that it's a sensational thing. I think there was more interest in Amber Heard Johnny Depp than Ukraine.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: There's lessons to be learned in these things, but I'm more interested in, if I'm going to follow any type of trials, I'm more interested in like tort cases against corporations than I am trying to, you know, put myself in the form of the jury.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Sure.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: But so, you know, I mean, the fact is, it was a neighboring town. It was a different state. I mean, people are saying it to make the point that what is his investment in this? I also think that like, yeah, it's a point, but it's a minor one. I don't think it's a huge point. And I don't think that I ever made a big deal of it. And to be honest with you, like I don't watch much other coverage of anything. You know, to the extent that I've even seen stuff that you've done, it's really only stuff that people send me. And so it's possible that people overplayed that in a way that was, I don't know, I guess in your mind, prejudicial towards him. But that's not, I mean, I'm agnostic as to that. I mean, it's certainly accurate to say, but if you think it gives the wrong impression of what he was doing there, okay.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: I mean, and like, I agree with everything you're saying now, but I mean, like, the idea that like, if you haven't followed much or don't know much about it, I think it's perfectly fine. I do that with a lot of stuff. But to say that and then simultaneously give really strong opinions about, I think, like the facts of the matter, I think.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: And he shot a third in the arm. And he went down there, according to him, to protect a car dealership.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Yeah, so I think that his buddy's friend was asking him to protect.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: Well, so to be clear,

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: a couple things. On the last part, the reason why people were down there was because on the 24th, the Kenosha Guard formed on Facebook in response to car dealership, over 100 cars, and neighboring buildings being set on fire on a block, right? So that's why that like little militia thing formed on Facebook. Now, whether you heard about it from Facebook or a friend that heard about it on Facebook, there was a reason why that had formed. It wasn't just randomly like, I'm going to go down to a place. Number one, for the second thing, I think that when I look at people's characterizations of events, I think we can be like a little bit more sophisticated than are the facts 100% like correct or incorrect. I think it goes a little bit deeper than that. Like, I'm sure you've heard people say like 1350 over and over again, right?

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: I don't know what 1350 is. Let's just stick with what I said that you have a problem with because I said he went down there to protect property. Well, so here I found out through Facebook that there was a partnership or according to the GQ story on him, which I think is the deepest reporting I've seen, it was from his friend regardless.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Yeah, well, so like things that you've said that are like kind of true but like a little bit like, so he killed two people with a gun because he killed people and went to a neighboring town to kill people. Like the characterization is kind of strange that he's like driving to a neighboring town. Like it's pretty common that people's communities, especially in rural areas, are in other areas. He's from a different town in a different state. He went down to protect either because he saw it on Facebook or because his friend said to protect a car dealership. That's what I said and then he killed people, which he did. True. Then also, the second thing is the idea that he's killing people to defend property, that isn't true either. He didn't kill anybody in defense of property.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: Why did he show up there with a gun?

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Obstensibly, as you've said, to protect property.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: Okay. What do you do with a gun to protect property? You would shoot people.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Okay. But he didn't shoot people protecting property.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: If I take a gun with me to a bar and I go to drink and somebody tries to assault me and then when that will go to a bar to protect the bar from people coming in and you know there's people coming in and you fire at them. I mean, that's what you're doing.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: I agree if that was the case but Rittenhouse wasn't shooting at people defending property. He shot at people that shot at him first and attacked him.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: He's patrolling around with a gun.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Yeah, but you have a second amendment right in the United States to have a firearm and that's his community as much as any other protesters.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: We're not talking about whether he had a right to do it.

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: Well, we are.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: He was commemorated from the question of murder. It's not a question whether he had a right to do it. I'm saying he's an asshole for doing it.

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: Well, he might be but he shot not only did he shoot people not only make the decision I'm going to go down there with a gun to protect property and if I'm going down there with a gun that means that if push comes to shove I'm going to shoot people and so whether he thought oh, I may end up having to shoot somebody because people will see the gun and come at me because I've got a gun and they want to disarm me or they want to come he's going into this situation with a gun not for the express purpose of anything other than to protect property right? He's not going there to protest these things and I'm not I'm not saying that I'm not defending people who were you know committing violence or any type of property destruction or I'm not defending anybody in this scenario

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: but I could he not have just brought the gun to protect himself if he thought somebody was going to attack him

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: why you know how you can protect yourself don't go there if you're worried that's in danger to you don't go there

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: so I can okay so digging in on the other side now this is this is what sounds like the liberal response like who cares if your community is on fire who cares if all of your stuff is being burned down who cares if people from outside the community are coming into protest which is what was happening as well the police when they released the arrest a lot of people weren't even from there just stay home and let in rural areas you know that people are going to show up or would you say the same about Koreans during the LA riots that they should have just stayed home they should have let their stuff burn down none of their friends should have showed up

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: I think it's perfectly legitimate you go into your store and you sit there as a way of protecting it but that's not what he did he was roaming the streets as if he was some type of like you know guardian angel or something and I had problems even with guardian angels in New York to some extent but at least they weren't out there with a weapon that is used explicitly to kill people I mean and then on top of which the video that you saw was not rehashing any of this it was talking about his appearance in right wing media because not only did this guy which I just and like I say perfectly within his right to decide he's going to go down and protect the city because of all the training he had or didn't have in protecting the city with you

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: know weapons like that which I think is just a incredibly irresponsible thing to do but then the guy is using it to make himself famous like I can conceive of a situation where a 17 or 18 year old kid whatever his age was specifically at that time and making this huge mistake of judgment like I'm going to go down there with a weapon I am not in any way trained to deal with this situation to do crowd control or whatever it is but I'm super psyched to do this and I can conceive of a kid going down there if you want to say in a completely innocent way and maiming a third in a completely innocent way and then after that happens and he gets exonerated on murder charges I can see if this guy then decides I'm going to take some time away and do some introspection and I'm going to because you see this all the time you can find YouTube videos of people who have killed people either accidentally I drunk drove and I hit somebody or it was dark and I hit somebody and they died or I punched somebody one time that they had taken two lives or a life and you know then I would think you know people make mistakes but the guy's just an asshole and that's really all I said I don't think I even said he was an asshole but the implication was he's an asshole and he's using the fact that he killed two people as a sort of mechanism in which to get fame I think that is I mean we talk about you know what's problematic in our

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: him trying to get fame I think is the natural consequence of how people on the left treat him if one side is going to cast you as a villain you

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: he's being cast in that light over and over and over again I don't think it's very surprising that he's going to run into the arms of people on the right that are going to embrace him as a hero especially given how much is factually incorrect about what's being stated about him how many times people say that he killed people in defense of property which wasn't true how many times people are willing to downplay the other protesters you keep mentioning the third guy that was maimed that guy got maimed running up to Rittenhouse with a glock that he was going to shoot him with and I think that the overall issue you have here is this constant downplaying of what was going on in Kenosha which was a community that

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: because he probably felt a calling to protect his community and I think given the totality of the action that you saw all the videos you saw well hold on wait let me finish real quick because you just want to okay lots of videos of him running around doing the medico medico whatever and we can say he's a dumb kid he's doing dumb shit sure but

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: people that are saying things there's videos that were released weeks before of him cleaning graffiti off his property I think trying to join some youth police or whatever bullshit it seems to me based on everything I've seen probably just a kid that was concerned about his community given that his dad lived there and he was a lifeguard there for some years that's not the most inconceivable thing ever given that his community was literally being destroyed given that all the videos show him showing up to clean up graffiti offer water bottles or whatever showing that all of the provocation that was on video was other people attacking him and that's what happened over and over and over the first shooting only happened after a guy behind the first victim got shot into the air behind him I don't think it's fair to say that Rittenhouse went there with the goal of being this bloodthirsty murder that was trying to protect property waiting to find somebody who was going to

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: say that no you didn't but this constant phrasing of what he's doing and then like a quote real quick you did a whole rebel you said like 20 things that I disagree with just real quick like you used this phrase I was concerned someone might go in and steal skittles like that was a phrase you used as well when talking about the destruction that was brought on this community and I

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: all black community setting fire to it I think everybody would have been on their high horses defending his right to be in that community and defend their property from white supremacists going through and marching through and burning stuff

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: okay you now like I I am not responsible for the nameless people that you're telling me have spread misinformation like I say I don't watch other shows I'm responsible for what I did now you in response and again I you know I only know this because somebody just sent this to me a day ago you said that I would be guzzling buckets of his cum if he was black and they were white okay so so now aside from you know the issue of whether I would guzzle buckets of

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: if there has never been a situation where this has taken place the reverse scenario you're talking about that may be instructive but you would never find me ever

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: celebrating and particularly a guy who is celebrating the killing of anybody ever and then you said I would be guzzling buckets of his cum that I'm assuming is your way of saying I'd be celebrating that and I'm telling you I've never done that I've never celebrated anybody killing anybody in any scenario whatsoever I've been doing this for 18 years three hours a day if it was out there you'd know it so you're the one who's actually doing what you accused me of doing I didn't do it you and I have a different opinion as to why this guy went there we'll never know

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: I still did not I still do not have any out there claiming I have some knowledge about his intent I said he went down there to protect property which is what he claimed he did that is a very generous I'm being perfectly you know I'm letting him

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: vigilantism regardless of who performs it is wrong and then I think using

blocks.speaker: A
blocks.text: that to build your fame is fucking gross and so I think the guy is an asshole and so you know that's all I've said on these videos and you've gone on to say like that a hypothetical situation where I'd be so excited I'd

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: okay so okay give me a second then okay so I'm not strim any so these are quotes that I've written down from your video so one was you said he killed two people with a gun because he killed people in the neighboring town which is technically true in the same way that white people are becoming minority in the United States but I wouldn't let a conservative get away with that latter statement because it's obvious what they're implying same as the former of what you're implying when you constantly you're implying that he's like traveling to some community that has no ties to and you said as much in this conversation that you're like well I don't know why he would go

blocks.speaker: B
blocks.text: the majority of people I know own guns sure but then I don't understand how it's so inconceivable that somebody might have like a town that they closely identify with like 15 20 miles away I'm from Nebraska like that's not uncommon depending on how far east or west you live like yeah everybody goes to Omaha everybody goes to go down and

blocks.speaker: A
